Vasopressin, also known as antidiuretic hormone, arginine vasopressin, argipressin, is a neurohypophysial hormone of most mammals.

Vasopressin's two main functions are to retain water in the body and to constrict blood vessels. It increases water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the nephrons of the kidneys, thereby maintaining body water levels.

Vasopressin is a peptide hormone. It increases blood pressure by increasing peripheral vascular resistance. It helps in homeostasis by regulating water, glucose and electrolytes in the blood. It is synthesized in the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary. Its half-life is 16-24 minutes.

Human vasopressin, also called antidiuretic hormone, arginine vasopressin, or argipressin, is a hormone that is synthesized as a peptide prohormone in neurons of the hypothalamus from the arginine vasopressin gene.
Vasopressin then travels down axons terminating in the posterior pituitary and is released from vesicles into the circulation in response to extracellular fluid hypertonicity (hyperosmolality).

Arginine vasopressin has two primary functions. First, it increases the amount of solute-free water reabsorbed from the renal tubules of the nephron into the circulation. Second, arginine vasopressin constricts the arteries, which increases peripheral vascular resistance and increases arterial blood pressure.

third function is possible. Some arginine vasopressin may be released directly from the hypothalamus into the brain and may play an important role in social behavior, sexual motivation and pair bonding, and maternal responses to stress.
Vasopressin induces stem cell differentiation into cardiomyocytes and promotes heart muscle homeostasis.

Vasopressin regulates the tonicity of body fluids. It is secreted from the posterior pituitary in response to hypertonicity and causes the kidneys to reabsorb solute-free water and return it to the circulation from the nephron tubules, thus returning the tonicity of body fluids to normal.

A side effect of this renal reabsorption of water is concentrated urine and decreased urine volume. Arginine vasopressin released in high concentrations can increase blood pressure by inducing moderate vasoconstriction.

Arginine vasopressin may also have various neurological effects in the brain. It may influence pair-bonding in voles. High-density distributions of the vasopressin receptor arginine vasopressinR1A in the ventral forebrain region of prairie voles have been shown to facilitate and coordinate reward circuits during partner preference formation, important for pair bond formation.

Vasopressin has the following main effects: increasing the water permeability of the distal convoluted tubules (DCT) and cortical collecting tubules (CCT), as well as the outer and inner medullary collecting ducts (OMCD and IMCD) of the kidney, thus allowing water reabsorption and excretion of more concentrated urine, i.e., antidiuresis. This occurs through increased transcription and insertion of water channels (aquaporin-2) in the apical membranes of collecting tubules and collecting duct epithelial cells.

Aquaporins allow water to move down their osmotic gradient and out of the nephron, increasing the amount of water reabsorbed from the filtrate (urine formation) back into the bloodstream. This effect is mediated by V2 receptors. Vasopressin also increases calcium concentration in collecting duct cells through episodic release from intracellular stores.
Vasopressin, acting through cAMP, also increases transcription of the aquaporin-2 gene, thus increasing the total number of aquaporin-2 molecules in the collecting duct cells.

Vasopressin has the following main effects: It increases the permeability of the inner medullary portion of the collecting duct to urea by regulating the cell surface expression of urea transporters, which facilitates its reabsorption into the medullary interstitium as it moves down the concentration gradient created by the removal of water from the connecting tubules, the cortical collecting duct, and the outer medullary collecting duct.
Organ_eng: Urea transporter cells, collecting ducts, medullary portion, connecting tubules

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin has the following main effects: a sharp increase in sodium absorption across the ascending loop of Henle. This adds to the countercurrent effect which subsequently aids in proper water reabsorption in the distal tubule and collecting duct.

The hormone vasopressin also stimulates the activity of NKCC2. Vasopressin stimulates sodium chloride reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the nephron by activating the signaling pathway. Vasopressin increases the trafficking of NKCC2 to the membrane and phosphorylates certain serine and threonine sites in the cytoplasmic N-terminal of NKCC2 located in the membrane, increasing its activity. Increased NKCC2 activity promotes water reabsorption in the collecting duct through aquaporin 2 channels by producing a hypo-osmotic filtrate.
Vasopressin released into the brain may have several functions: Vasopressin is released into the brain in a circadian rhythm by neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
Vasopressin, released from the posterior pituitary, is associated with nausea.
Recent evidence suggests that vasopressin may have analgesic effects. The analgesia effects of vasopressin have been shown to be dependent on both stress and sex.

Many factors affect the release of vasopressin: Ethanol (alcohol) reduces the calcium-dependent release of arginine vasopressin by blocking voltage-gated calcium channels in neurohypophyseal nerve terminals in rats.

Many factors influence the release of vasopressin: Angiotensin II stimulates the release of arginine vasopressin in conjunction with its general pressor and pro-volumetric effects on the body. Atrial natriuretic peptide inhibits the release of arginine vasopressin, partially blocking the angiotensin II-induced stimulation of arginine vasopressin secretion. Cortisol inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone.
The physiological stimulus for vasopressin secretion is an increase in plasma osmolality, which is monitored by the hypothalamus.

The physiological stimulus for vasopressin secretion is an increase in plasma osmolality, which is monitored by the hypothalamus. Decreased arterial blood volume, (as can occur in cirrhosis, nephrosis, and heart failure), stimulates secretion, even in the face of decreased plasma osmolality: it overshoots the osmolality, but with a milder effect.
When arterial blood volume is low, unloading of arterial baroreceptors stimulates vasopressin secretion despite hypoosmolality (hyponatremia).

Almost all of the arginine vasopressin measured in peripheral blood is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland. Vasopressin is produced by magnocellular neurosecretory neurons in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and supraoptic nucleus. It then travels down the axon through the infundibulum into neurosecretory granules found within Hering's bodies, local swellings of axons and nerve terminals. These transport the peptide directly to the pituitary gland, where it is stored until it is released into the blood.
Common Medical Terms_eng: Neurosecretory neuron, axon, nerve terminal, Hering body, infundibulum

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin concentration is used to measure surgical pressure to evaluate surgical technique. Plasma vasopressin concentration is elevated by noxious stimuli, mainly during abdominal surgery, especially intestinal manipulation, visceral traction, as well as with carbon dioxide during abdominal laparoscopic surgery.
Vasopressin is used to manage antidiuretic hormone deficiency. Vasopressin is used to treat diabetes insipidus associated with low levels of antidiuretic hormone. It is available as Pressin.
Vasopressin has off-label uses and is used to treat vasodilatory shock, gastrointestinal bleeding, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation.
Disease_eng: Vasodilatory shock, gastrointestinal bleeding, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin agonists are used therapeutically in a variety of conditions, and its long-acting synthetic analogue desmopressin is used to control bleeding with reduced vasopressin secretion (in some forms of von Willebrand disease and mild hemophilia A) and in extreme cases, in bedwetting by children. Vasopressin analogues began to be used in the oesophagus in the 1970s.
Disease_eng: Von Willebrand disease, mild hemophilia A

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin infusions are also used as second-line therapy for patients with septic shock who do not respond to fluid resuscitation or catecholamines (e.g., dopamine or norepinephrine) to increase blood pressure and who are using catecholamines.

This arginine vasopressin has a much shorter elimination half-life (approximately 20 minutes) and a longer elimination half-life of many hours compared to synthetic non-arginine vasopressin. Furthermore, arginine acts on V1A, V1B, and V2 receptors, which in turn leads to higher EGFR and vascular resistance in the lungs. Several injectable arginine vasopressins are currently in clinical use in the United States and Europe.
Vasopressin is administered through an intravenous device, intramuscular injection, or a subcutaneous injection.

Vasopressin is administered by intravenous infusion, intramuscular injection, or subcutaneous injection. The duration of action depends on the mode of administration and ranges from thirty minutes to two hours. It has a half-life of ten to twenty minutes. It is widely distributed throughout the body and is present in extracellular fluids. It is metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. Arginine vasopressin tablets for use in septic shock are intended for intravenous use only.
The most common side effects during treatment with vasopressin are dizziness, angina, chest pain, abdominal pain, heartburn, nausea, vomiting.
The most common side effects during treatment with vasopressin are shivering, fever, water intoxication, lightheadedness, diarrhea, sweating, pallor, and flatulence.
Serious adverse reactions to vasopressin include myocardial infarction and hypersensitivity.
The use of lysine vasopressin is contraindicated in the presence of hypersensitivity to beef or pork protein and chronic renal failure.
Vasopressin is recommended to be used with caution in cases of perioperative polyuria, drug hypersensitivity, asthma, seizures, and heart failure.
Organ_eng: Urinary tract, kidneys, heart, respiratory tract
Disease_eng: Perioperative polyuria, drug hypersensitivity, asthma, seizures, heart failure

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin is recommended to be used with caution in cases of comatose states, migraine headaches, and cardiovascular disease.
Vasopressin has been shown to have effects on pain perception and cognitive function. Vasopressin plays a role in autism, major depressive disorder.
Vasopressin also plays a role in bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

Vasopressin is a hormone that plays an important role in maintaining osmolality (the concentration of dissolved particles such as salt and glucose in the serum) and therefore the amount of water in the extracellular fluid (the fluid space surrounding the cells). This is necessary to protect cells from sudden increases or decreases in water content, which can interfere with proper cell function. Normal serum osmolality ranges from about 285 to 300 milliosmoles per kilogram in healthy people.
Vasopressin and oxytocin are derived from a single primitive neurohypophyseal hormone called vasotocin, which is present in lower vertebrates.

Special nerve cells called osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus are very sensitive to changes in serum osmolality. Osmoreceptors are closely related to the same nerve cells that produce and secrete vasopressin.

Serum osmolality that increases or decreases by as much as 1 percent can cause a distinct decrease or increase in vasopressin secretion. The immediate effect of an increase in serum osmolality—for example, if a person becomes dehydrated (i.e., loses water through excessive sweating)—is a stimulation of osmoreceptors. This stimulation leads to the dissociation of vasopressin from the neurophysin molecule, where vasopressin is loosely bound within the secretory cell.

Vasopressin is then released from the pituitary gland, which then retains water in the kidneys. Conversely, the immediate effect of a decrease in serum osmolality—for example, if a person becomes overhydrated (i.e., drinks too much water)—is inhibition of osmoreceptors. This inhibition leads to a decrease in vasopressin secretion and a subsequent increase in water excretion. Osmoreceptors are also closely linked to the thirst center, which is stimulated by high serum osmolality and inhibited by low serum osmolality, similar to vasopressin secretion.

In the kidneys, vasopressin acts on the cells of the collecting ducts. These cells have receptors for vasopressin that are associated with vesicles that contain special water channels (aquaporins). When the cells are stimulated by vasopressin, the aquaporins bind to regions of the cell membrane that are in contact with urine, allowing water to enter the cells. The water then returns to the circulation. This reduces the volume of urine and increases the amount of sodium, chloride, and other substances in the urine. When this happens, the urine is said to be concentrated.
Disease_eng: Kidney problems and water balance problems

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin is also released in response to decreased blood volume. Special pressure sensors called baroreceptors can detect arterial blood pressure; these are located in the carotid sinuses, which are closely associated with each carotid artery high in the neck, and in a group of specialized cells in the left atrium of the heart.
Organ_eng: Carotid sinus, left atrium of the heart

Medical Text_eng: When blood volume increases, the tissues of the carotid sinus and left atrium expand and the nerves of the baroreceptors are stimulated. These nerves carry impulses to vasopressin-producing nerve cells that inhibit the release of vasopressin, thereby increasing water excretion.
Organ_eng: Carotid sinus, left atrium, pituitary gland

Medical Text_eng: If blood volume is reduced, carotid sinus and left atrial dilation is reduced, vasopressin secretion increases, and water excretion decreases, thereby helping to restore blood volume to normal. Other stimuli for vasopressin release include pain, stress, and several drugs, including opioids.
Organ_eng: Carotid sinus, left atrium, pituitary gland
Common Medical Terms_eng: Blood volume, expansion, secretion, water excretion, stress, pain

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin is similar to the anti-diarrheal hormone, which is normally produced by the body's pituitary gland.
The drug increases water retention in the body by forming vasopressin urine. This helps the kidneys absorb water effectively.

Vasopressin increases blood pressure by constricting blood vessels. Doctors usually prescribe it to treat diabetes insipidus, which occurs when the pituitary gland is unable to secrete anti-diarrheal hormone.
Before you start taking vasopressin, tell your doctor about any medical conditions you may have. These include coronary heart disease, asthma, migraine headaches, and kidney problems.

Pregnant women should only take vasopressin on the advice of a doctor. The drug can cause early labor if taken in the final months of pregnancy. The drug is usually injected through the anus, or administered into a muscle.

Vasopressin is a drug that is injected into the vein, or into a muscle. The injection is usually given by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. Some common side effects of this medication include stomach cramps, pale skin, sweating, gas, and tremors in the hands and feet.
Organ_eng: Stomach, intestines, sweat glands, nerves, blood vessels, thyroid gland

Medical Text_eng: The main side effects of vasopressin that anyone may encounter are dizziness, drowsiness, unconsciousness, breathing problems, and irregular heartbeat.
Adverse effects of vasopressin include: headache, slow heart rate
Adverse effects of vasopressin: abdominal cramps, skin discoloration
Adverse effects of vasopressin: increased blood pressure, stomach pain, diarrhea
If you miss a dose of vasopressin, skip it and continue with your normal schedule. Do not double the dose.
Vasopressin is a naturally occurring hormone primarily involved in regulating extracellular osmolarity, although it also plays a role in regulating the function of the cardiovascular system.
Vasopressin also has a strong vasoconstrictive effect, and it is this effect that is used in its role as a blood circulation aid.
Disease_eng: High blood pressure, low blood pressure

Medical Text_eng: There has been a small randomized trial (n = 20) comparing dopamine with vasopressin in hypotensive preterm infants.

The results were limited to physiological parameters and both agents had similar effects on BP increase with vasopressin having less tachycardic effect. There are small case series of improvement in BP in preterm infants with otherwise inotrope refractory hypotension.

There is some evidence from animal studies that vasopressin has vasodilatory effects on the pulmonary vasculature. This would be consistent with an observational report of vasopressin use in 10 children with PPHN refractory to inhaled nitric oxide (INO).
Vasopressin infusion improves blood pressure, reduces oxygenation index, and improves urine output.
There is insufficient safety data to recommend routine use of vasopressin, but it may have a role in the treatment of vasodilatory shock refractory to vasopressor-inotropes.

Vasopressin V1 receptors cause vasoconstriction due to contraction of vascular smooth muscle. In combination with norepinephrine, it has been shown to be effective and safe for the treatment of patients with septic shock.

In situations of cardiopulmonary arrest, vasopressin has similar efficacy to epinephrine for resuscitating patients with ventricular fibrillation or pulseless electrical activity, and is more effective in the presence of asystole.

It was found in patients that under dopamine therapy, the addition of vasopressin was non-inferior to norepinephrine as assessed by increases in mean BP and other hemodynamic parameters, although no benefit was seen in terms of mortality.
good response to vasopressin was also observed in hypotensive patients after LV assist device placement, reducing their need for norepinephrine.
Vasopressin is a peptide hormone that is synthesized in the hypothalamus and transported and stored in the pituitary.

Vasopressin is released in response to decreases in blood volume and osmolality. Vascular smooth muscle cells are directly affected by vasopressin through V1 receptors. It also acts to increase vascular responsiveness to catecholamines. 26 Under nonseptic conditions, vasopressin has little effect on blood pressure.
Organ_eng: Vascular smooth muscle cells, pituitary gland

Medical Text_eng: During hypovolemia, it may prevent confusion in the vascular response to shock. The Vasopressin vs. Norepinephrine in Septic Shock Study reported no difference in 28-day mortality in the septic shock group treated with either agent. Vasopressin performed better in a subgroup analysis of less severely affected patients. Furthermore, vasopressin added to a moderate dose of norepinephrine is as safe and effective as norepinephrine alone in fluid-resuscitated patients with septic shock. In this setting, patients may benefit from a lower dose of norepinephrine with vasopressin, rather than a higher dose of norepinephrine alone.
Vasopressin is an endogenous peptide that is expressed in the hypothalamus.
The initial prohormone preprovasopressin is converted to provasopressin and vasopressin in the pituitary gland.
Vasopressin causes vasoconstriction through stimulation of V1 receptors in smooth muscle. In addition, it has a vasodilatory effect on cerebral and renal arteries through stimulation of V2 receptors.
Organ_eng: Smooth muscle, cerebral arteries, renal arteries

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin is an endogenous hormone that causes vasoconstriction (V1 receptors) and water reabsorption in the renal tubules (V2 receptors). In experimental models of cardiac arrest, vasopressin increases blood flow to the heart and brain and improves long-term survival compared with epinephrine.

Vasopressin is a potent hormone responsible for regulating plasma volume and osmolality. It is bound to the carrier protein neurohypophysin, which participates in its transport along the supraoptic hypophyseal tract to the axon terminals.

In the early stages of septic shock, plasma vasopressin levels are elevated, but they decrease in later septic patients. Therefore, vasopressin levels may be good candidates for assessing the risk and prognosis of septic shock. Further studies are needed to prove their usefulness as an early marker of sepsis. It binds to the carrier protein neurohypophysin, which is transported to axon terminals along the supraoptic hypophyseal tract.

Vasopressin is an endogenous peptide hormone that produces contraction of vascular smooth muscle via V receptors, which are ubiquitous in the systemic circulation, especially in the skin and splanchnic vessels. It is considered a nonadrenergic vasopressor adjunct in the treatment of sepsis-associated hypotension.
Organ_eng: Vascular smooth muscle, skin, splanchnic vessels

Medical Text_eng: Under normal physiological conditions, vasopressin is primarily responsible for free water homeostasis. In healthy subjects, it is associated with only moderate vasoconstriction in the pulmonary and renal arterial systems and, at very low levels, can lead to pulmonary vasodilation through the release of endothelial nitric oxide.

The effect of vasopressin on arterial tone becomes more significant in cases of acute hypotension, when it is released from the neurohypophysis at concentrations that are several hundred times higher than basal levels. Endogenous vasopressin stores may be depleted within hours of the onset of shock. In this setting, normalization of circulating concentrations with exogenous administration may result in marked peripheral vasoconstriction and increases in systolic and diastolic pressures.
At standard therapeutic doses, vasopressin is considered a "catecholamine-sparing" agent in severe sepsis and is often used in combination with norepinephrine.

The main cardiovascular effect of vasopressin is vasoconstriction in multiple vascular beds, including the coronary circulation, mediated by its action on V, which shows that survivors of resuscitation had higher levels of stress hormones during CPR than nonsurvivors. Hormones measured during CPR included adrenocorticotropin, cortisol, renin, and vasopressin.

Vasopressin or antidiuretic hormone is a potent endogenous hormone, responsible for regulating plasma osmolality and volume. At high concentrations, it also increases blood pressure by inducing moderate vasoconstriction. It acts as a neurotransmitter in the brain to control circadian rhythms, thermoregulation, and adrenocorticotropic hormone release.

The therapeutic use of vasopressin in the critical care setting has become increasingly important in the management of cranial diabetes insipidus, bleeding abnormalities, esophageal variceal hemorrhage, asystolic cardiac arrest, and septic shock. After 10 years of ongoing research, vasopressin has become a potential component of the anesthesiologist's armamentarium as a vasopressor agent in the treatment of cardiac arrest and severe shock conditions.
Disease_eng: Cranial diabetes insipidus, bleeding abnormalities, esophageal variceal hemorrhage, asystolic cardiac arrest, septic shock

Medical Text_eng: The use of vasopressin during cardiopulmonary resuscitation may improve survival in patients with asystolic cardiac arrest.

Low doses of vasopressin can restore vasomotor tone in catecholamine-resistant states with preservation of renal blood flow and urine output. It may also be effective in reducing bleeding and mortality associated with esophageal variceal hemorrhage. Terlipressin is a useful vasopressin analog that increases blood pressure stability in septic patients.

Vasopressin is a nonpeptide synthesized as a prohormone in the cell bodies of magnocellular neurons in the paraventricular and posterior hypothalamus. It is bound to a carrier protein, neurohypophysin, and transported along the supraoptic hypophyseal tract to the axonal terminals of magnocellular neurons located in the posterior pituitary. Synthesis, transport, and storage take 1–2 hours.
Organ_eng: Paraventricular hypothalamus, posterior hypothalamus, posterior pituitary

Medical Text_eng: Given its systemic vasoconstrictive and local vasodilatory effects on the arteries of the circle of Willis, vasopressin has also been used to ensure adequate cerebral perfusion pressure in the perioperative setting. Ye et al reported the successful administration of vasopressin in a patient suffering from spontaneous cerebellar and subarachnoid hemorrhage with advanced vasodilatory shock, neurogenic pulmonary edema, and myocardial dysfunction.
Disease_eng: Spontaneous cerebellar and subarachnoid hemorrhage, neurogenic pulmonary edema, myocardial dysfunction

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressin is a safe combined vasopressor with phenylephrine for hypervolemic, hemodilutional, and hypertensive treatment of patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage. Vasopressin does not induce vasospasm or exacerbate electrolyte disturbances.

Vasopressin reduces portal blood flow, portal systemic collateral flow, and variceal pressure through V1 receptors. Its side-effects include increased peripheral resistance; decreased cardiac output, and decreased coronary blood flow, which are reduced when combined with glyceryl trinitrate.

Severe skin necrosis has been reported following extravasation of low-dose vasopressin administered for catecholamine-resistant shock, and peripheral administration of low-dose vasopressin infusions should be discouraged. Anaphylaxis, bronchospasm, urticaria, and gastrointestinal tract ischemia have been reported with clinical use. Decreased cardiac output and systemic oxygen delivery, impaired intestinal mucosal and hepatic oxygenation, increased aminotransferase activity and bilirubin concentrations, and decreased platelet count have also been observed.

Sodium concentration and plasma osmolality should be assessed routinely, although to date there is no evidence that vasopressin analogues are associated with antidiuresis, water retention, or renal impairment in patients with septic shock. Conversely, several studies have reported benefits as well as improvements in renal function compared with catecholamine therapy alone in patients at risk of acute renal failure.
Vasopressors constrict or tighten your blood vessels, causing your heart to contract more forcefully. All of this helps your body distribute blood to your vital organs.
Vasopressor therapy helps with a number of conditions, including: shock, systolic heart failure (your heart can't pump hard enough). Heart attack. Sepsis. Pulmonary embolism (blood clot).
Disease_eng: Shock, systolic heart failure, heart attack, sepsis, pulmonary embolism
Common Medical Terms_eng: Shock, systolic heart failure, heart attack

Medical Text_eng: Vasopressor therapy helps with a number of conditions, including: Aortic stenosis (narrowing of your aorta). Pulmonary hypertension (high blood pressure in your lungs). Cardiac tamponade (fluid around your heart puts pressure on it). Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (thickened heart muscle). Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
Disease_eng: Aortic stenosis, pulmonary hypertension, cardiac tamponade, hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy

Medical Text_eng: Side effects of vasopressors include: Anxiety. Headache. Chest pain. Pulmonary edema (fluid in your lungs). Difficulty breathing.
Bradycardia (slow heart rate). Thromboembolism (blood clot). Thrombocytopenia (low blood platelets). These are side effects of vasopressors.

Tachycardia (fast heart rate). Ventricular arrhythmia (heart rhythm problems). Atrial fibrillation. Severe high blood pressure that can lead to bleeding in your brain or sudden cardiac death. These are among the side effects of vasopressors.
Disease_eng: Tachycardia, ventricular arrhythmia, atrial fibrillation, hypertension

Medical Text_eng: Somatropin is intended for hormone therapy. It is used to treat hormone-related growth deficiency disorders, certain intestinal diseases, or HIV-related weight loss, physical development, and growth.
Disease_eng: Growth deficiency, certain intestinal diseases, HIV-related weight loss

Medical Text_eng: Somatropin can also be administered to children with birth defects who are unable to grow tall for their age. You must consult your doctor about the dosage of this medicine, especially if you are pregnant, planning to get pregnant soon, or breastfeeding.
If you have a history of liver, kidney, lung, or heart disease, or if you are allergic to any medications, foods, or substances, you should inform your doctor before taking somatropin.

Discuss with your doctor any other prescription medications you are taking, such as dietary supplements, as somatropin may interact with other medications and cause several health complications. In this situation, make sure you take the necessary precautions. This medication can be administered intravenously or subcutaneously, depending on the patient's needs.

Some common side effects of somatropin include persistent headaches, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, extreme fatigue, unusual weight gain, unusual increased thirst, some unusual body aches, numbness or tingling in the hands and feet.
You may also experience serious side effects such as decreased heart rate as a result of somatropin.
Somatropin may increase the risk of certain types of cancer, including brain or skin cancer.

Somatropin injection is used to replace growth hormone (a natural hormone produced by your body) in adults and children with growth hormone deficiency. Somatropin injection is also used to increase growth in children with certain conditions that affect normal growth and development.
Somatropin injection (Serostim) is used to increase body weight and physical endurance in patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) who have HIV-associated wasting syndrome.
Somatropin injection is used to treat short bowel syndrome in adults who are receiving extra nutrition or fluids from intravenous therapy.

Somatropin is a human growth hormone (HGH) analogue. It works by replacing the growth hormones normally produced in the body, which can lead to growth, body weight, and improved absorption of nutrients and fluids from the intestines.
Somatropin injection is given to replace growth hormone in adults, usually once a day.
Somatropin injection is used to replace growth hormone or to increase growth in children, usually once every 3 to 7 days.
Somatropin injection comes as a solution (liquid) in prefilled dosing pens and cartridges, and as a powder mixed with liquid in vials and cartridges that is injected subcutaneously (under the skin).
When somatropin injection (Serostim) is given to patients with HIV-related wasting syndrome to increase body weight and exercise endurance, it is usually given once daily or once every other day.
When somatropin injection (Zorbtiv) is given to treat short bowel syndrome, it is usually given once daily for 4 weeks.

Use somatropin injection at about the same time each day. Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. Use somatropin injection exactly as directed. Do not use more or less of it, or take it more often than your doctor tells you to.

Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to somatropin, any other medications, benzyl alcohol, or any of the ingredients in somatropin injection. Ask your pharmacist or see the medication guide for a list of ingredients.

Tell your doctor if you have recently had heart or stomach surgery, an accident or trauma, or severe breathing problems, or if you have sleep apnea (stopping breathing for short periods of time while sleeping), cancer, or diabetic retinopathy (damage to the eyes caused by diabetes). Your doctor may tell you not to use somatropin injection.
Disease_eng: Heart disease, sleep apnea, cancer, diabetic retinopathy

Medical Text_eng: Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. If you become pregnant while using somatropin injection, call your doctor. If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using somatropin injection.

Somatropin may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: skin thickening at the injection site, pain, redness, swelling, or itching at the injection site, headache, muscle or joint pain.
Sore throat, cough, fever, or other signs of infection Earache Bloating or excessive gas in the intestines or bowels Hair loss These are side effects of somatropin.

Some side effects of somatropin can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms, stop taking it and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: vision changes, headache, nausea and vomiting; hives; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; sweating; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat; lightheadedness; fainting; or chest pain.
Organ_eng: Respiratory system, heart, eyes, throat, head

Medical Text_eng: Ongoing pain that starts in the stomach area but may spread to the back Nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite Numbness, burning, tingling, or prickling in the hands, fingers, arms, legs, or feet Swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs These are side effects of somatropin.

Some side effects of somatropin can be serious: extreme tiredness, muscle or joint pain, weakness, lightheadedness, darkening of the skin, or weight loss; new or persistent knee or hip pain, lip breathing, snoring, or sleep apnea; enlarged breasts.
Call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following symptoms as a result of somatropin: changes in behavior or vision; headaches; or changes in moles, birthmarks, or skin color.

Symptoms of an overdose of somatropin may include: Swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs Excessive sweating and body odor Increased swelling of the hands, feet, lips, nose, and tongue Joint or muscle weakness
Human growth hormone, commonly known as somatropin, is produced by the healthy human body by the pituitary gland, located at the base of the brain.

Somatropin is believed to combat many of the common symptoms of aging, including bone fragility, decreased ability to think and remember clearly, deterioration of skin tone, and muscle weakness. It is also believed to slow the progression of heart disease.
Somatropin injection is indicated for the treatment of pediatric patients with growth failure due to inadequate secretion of the endogenous growth hormone somatropin.
Somatropin injection is indicated for the treatment of short stature pediatric patients associated with Noonan syndrome.
Somatropin injection is indicated for the treatment of pediatric patients with short stature associated with Turner syndrome.
Somatropin injection is indicated for the treatment of pediatric patients who are born small for gestational age and do not show any catch-up growth between the ages of 2 and 4 years.

Adult Patients: Somatropin injection is indicated for the replacement of endogenous GH in adults who meet either of the following two criteria for growth hormone deficiency: Adult-onset: Patients with growth hormone deficiency associated with single or multiple hormone deficiencies (hypopituitarism) resulting from pituitary disease, hypothalamic disease, surgery, radiation therapy, or trauma; or Childhood-onset: Patients who had growth hormone deficiency in childhood due to congenital, genetic, acquired, or idiopathic causes.
The most common side effects of somatropin include headache, muscle pain, joint stiffness, high blood sugar (hyperglycemia), sugar in your urine (glucosuria).
The drug somatropin can cause serious allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis and angioedema, which can be life-threatening and require immediate medical attention.

The presence of other medical problems may affect the use of somatropin. Be sure to tell your doctor if you have any other medical problems, especially: brain tumor or cancer, active or normal bone growth in children, or diabetic retinopathy (an eye condition).

The presence of other medical problems may affect the use of somatropin medication. In particular: it should not be used in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome (a genetic disorder), if severely overweight or if there is severe breathing difficulty, or if there is a serious illness or major medical emergency after surgery (e.g., open heart surgery, abdominal surgery, accidental injury, or respiratory failure).

The presence of other medical problems may affect the use of this somatropin medication. Be sure to tell your doctor if you have any other medical problems, especially: cancer, history or fluid retention, history or hypopituitarism (the pituitary gland produces fewer hormones) or hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid gland).
Children with otitis media (ear infection), history of, or pancreatitis (inflammation or swelling of the pancreas) may affect the use of somatropin medication.
-Use somatropin with caution if you have scoliosis (abnormally curved spine). This condition may worsen.

Diabetes, or family history—Use with caution. May prevent insulin or other diabetes medications from working properly. . Kidney disease—Use with caution. Effects may be increased due to slower removal of the drug from the body. The presence of these medical problems may affect the use of this somatropin medication.

Turner syndrome - Use with caution. May increase the risk of serious problems (such as problems with the pancreas, thyroid, or heart and blood vessels, ear or hearing problems, diabetes, increased pressure in the head, and bone problems including dislocation of the hip bone or scoliosis). The presence of other medical problems may affect the use of somatropin. Be sure to tell your doctor if you have any other medical problems, especially Turner syndrome.
Organ_eng: Pancreas, thyroid, heart, blood vessels, ears, bones

Medical Text_eng: Pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) has rarely occurred in some patients taking somatropin. Tell your doctor immediately if you or your child have sudden and severe stomach pain, chills, constipation, nausea, vomiting, fever, or lightheadedness.

Somatropin can cause hip dislocation, especially in patients with growth hormone deficiency or Turner syndrome. Contact your doctor immediately if you or your child has any swelling or pain in the hip or knee.

If you take this somatropin medicine for a long time, contact your doctor immediately if you experience dark skin, diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, loss of appetite, depression, nausea, skin rash, unusual tiredness or weakness, or vomiting. These may be signs of adrenal gland problems (hypoadrenalism).

The following are side effects of somatropin: Skin color changes Chest tightness Chills Flu-like symptoms Cold hands and feet Confusion Constipation Cough or hoarseness Dark urine Decreased urination Diarrhea Difficulty urinating

Contact your doctor immediately if any of the following somatropin side effects occur: dizziness, dry mouth. Fainting or loss of consciousness, fast heartbeat, fast or irregular breathing. Feeling unusually cold. Fever or chills. Feeling full or swollen. A general feeling of discomfort or illness. Headache. Increased heart rate, itching or skin rash, joint pain, light-colored stools, lightheadedness, loss of appetite, pain in the lower back or side, muscle pain or cramping, muscle pain or stiffness, nausea, or swelling in the arms or legs.
Human chorionic gonadotropin is a hormone that helps a woman's ovaries develop normally.
Gonadotropins stimulate an egg during ovulation, treat infertility in women, pituitary gland disorders in young boys, underdeveloped sexual characteristics in girls, and increase sperm count in men.
Human chorionic gonadotropin is injected directly into the skin or muscle.

Before starting gonadotropin medication, tell your doctor if you have any of the following conditions: thyroid or adrenal gland disorders, cancer or tumors of the breast, uterus, ovaries, hypothalamus, prostate, or pituitary gland.
Organ_eng: Thyroid, adrenal glands, breasts, uterus, ovaries, hypothalamus, pituitary gland
Disease_eng: Adrenal gland disorders, cancer, breast tumors

Medical Text_eng: If you have unexplained uterine bleeding, heart or kidney disease, epilepsy, migraines, or asthma, tell your doctor before starting gonadotropin medication.

Some of the side effects of using human chorionic gonadotropin include severe pelvic pain, swelling in the hands and feet, stomach pain, shortness of breath, weight gain, diarrhea, nausea or vomiting, and urinating less than usual.
Less serious side effects of gonadotropins include headache, feeling restless and jittery, water weight gain, depression, breast swelling, and mild pain.
Gonadotropin medication has been used to treat infertility in women who have not gone through menopause but who cannot conceive due to hormonal imbalances in the body.
Gonadotropin medications are used to treat male infertility caused by a deficiency in the secretion of certain hormones in the body.
This medicine is not recommended for use if you have a known history of allergy to gonadotropin medications.
This gonadotropin medication is not recommended for use if a male patient has or is suspected of having prostate cancer.
Side effects of human chorionic gonadotropin include: flatulence, stomach pain, pelvic pain, nausea or vomiting, rapid weight gain.
Allergic skin reactions, itching, breast enlargement, headache, pain at the injection site, insomnia. These are the harmful effects of human chorionic gonadotropin.

This gonadotropin medication is not used by breastfeeding women unless absolutely necessary. Special precautions should be taken while taking this medication and breastfeeding should be discontinued during treatment. Consult your doctor before deciding to take this medication and discuss the risks and benefits.
Gonadotropins are glycoprotein hormones secreted by the gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary in the spinal cord.
Gonadotropins act on the gonads, controlling the production of gametes and sex hormones.
There are various preparations of gonadotropins for therapeutic use, mainly as fertility drugs.
Human gonadotropin is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is produced by the placenta during pregnancy.

Gonadotropins are secreted from the arcuate nucleus and preoptic area of the hypothalamus under the control of gonadotropin-releasing hormone. The gonads - testes and ovaries - are the primary target organs for LH and FSH.

Hypogonadism results from a deficiency of gonadotropins due to pituitary disease, which can cause infertility. Treatment includes administered gonadotropins, which, therefore, act as fertility drugs. These can be produced either by extraction and purification from urine or by recombinant DNA.
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is a releasing hormone that is responsible for the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary.
Hormones_eng: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone

Medical Text_eng: Gonadotropin is a tropic peptide hormone synthesized and secreted from gonadotropin-releasing hormone neurons in the hypothalamus. It belongs to the peptide gonadotropin-releasing hormone family. It forms the initial step of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone is found in organs outside the hypothalamus and pituitary, and its role in other life processes is poorly understood. For example, gonadotropin-releasing hormone may have a role in the placenta and gonads. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone and gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptors are also found in cancers of the breast, ovary, prostate, and endometrium.
Organ_eng: Hypothalamus, pituitary, placenta, gonads, breast, ovary, prostate, endometrium
Disease_eng: Breast cancer, ovarian cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer

Medical Text_eng: Calcitonin is a hormone that plays a role in regulating the level of calcium in your blood. The C-cells in your thyroid gland produce calcitonin. There do not appear to be any direct negative side effects from having abnormal levels of calcitonin in your body.

Calcitonin is a hormone that your thyroid gland makes and helps control the level of calcium in your blood by lowering it. Calcitonin opposes the action of parathyroid hormone, which is a hormone that increases the level of calcium in your blood.

Your thyroid is a small, butterfly-shaped gland located under your skin in the front of your neck. It is part of your endocrine system and controls many important functions in your body by producing and secreting (secreting) certain hormones. The C-cells (parafollicular cells) in your thyroid produce and secrete calcitonin.

In the past, healthcare providers prescribed synthetic (manufactured) forms of calcitonin as medications to treat Paget's disease of bone, hypercalcemia, and osteoporosis. However, with the introduction of newer medications such as bisphosphonates, providers rarely use this form of calcitonin for treatment.
Disease_eng: Paget's disease of bone, hypercalcemia, osteoporosis

Medical Text_eng: Calcitonin's main function is to lower the level of calcium in your blood.

Calcitonin inhibits (blocks) the activity of osteoclasts, which are cells that break down bone. When osteoclasts break down your bones, calcium is released from your bones into your bloodstream. Therefore, the temporary blockade of osteoclasts by calcitonin reduces the amount of calcium that enters your blood.
Calcitonin can reduce the amount of calcium that your kidneys reabsorb and release into your bloodstream, thus lowering blood calcium levels.

Your thyroid releases calcitonin based on the level of calcium in your blood. When your blood calcium levels rise, your thyroid releases more calcitonin. When your blood calcium levels fall, your thyroid releases less calcitonin.
Both parathyroid hormone and calcitonin help regulate the level of calcium in your blood, which is necessary for a variety of important bodily functions.

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a hormone that your parathyroid glands make and release to help regulate the level of calcium in your blood by increasing it. PTH also helps regulate the levels of phosphorus (a mineral) and vitamin D (a hormone) in your blood and bones. There are four pea-sized parathyroid glands behind your thyroid gland.

Parathyroid hormone increases blood calcium levels, while calcitonin decreases blood calcium levels. However, parathyroid hormone appears to have a more important role in regulating your blood calcium levels than calcitonin. Scientists know this mainly because high or low levels of parathyroid hormone can cause hypercalcemia (high blood calcium levels) or hypocalcemia (low blood calcium levels), respectively, which can be serious conditions. On the other hand, high or low levels of calcitonin don't have much effect on your body.

Calcitriol, a hormone also known as active vitamin D, helps your intestines absorb calcium from the food you eat and release it into your bloodstream. Calcitriol prevents calcium loss from your kidneys. Parathyroid hormone is responsible for stimulating the enzyme that converts vitamin D from sunlight in your skin into calcitriol.
Calcitonin lowers calcium levels by preventing the breakdown of calcium in bones and preventing your kidneys from reabsorbing calcium. In other words, it promotes calcium loss through your kidneys.

Because abnormal calcitonin levels do not cause symptoms in and of themselves, providers usually only order a calcitonin blood test for the following reasons: To help diagnose medullary thyroid cancer or C-cell hyperplasia. To monitor treatment for medullary thyroid cancer.

Your healthcare provider can check your calcitonin levels with a blood test. This uses a needle to draw a sample of blood from a vein in your arm. Because abnormal calcitonin levels do not cause symptoms in themselves, providers usually only order a calcitonin blood test for the following reasons: If you have a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2, an inherited condition that is associated with three primary types of endocrine tumors, including MTC.

Having high levels of calcitonin can be a sign of a rare condition, including: Medullary thyroid cancer: This is a rare thyroid cancer that arises in the C-cells of your thyroid gland — the cells that make calcitonin. Because of this, medullary thyroid cancer can cause those cells to produce excessive amounts of calcitonin. Although the excess calcitonin does not affect your body, MTC can and often does spread to other tissues (metastasize), especially to the lymph nodes.

Higher-than-normal levels of calcitonin do not appear to negatively affect your body or cause symptoms. However, having high levels of calcitonin can be a sign of one of several rare conditions, including: C-cell hyperplasia: This is a benign (noncancerous) condition that causes an abnormal growth of C-cells in your thyroid. The enlarged tissue can release excess calcitonin. C-cell hyperplasia can sometimes develop into medullary thyroid cancer.

High concentrations of calcitonin may be able to increase urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate via the renal tubules, leading to marked hypocalcemia. However, this is a secondary effect that has no physiological significance in humans. It is also a short-lived effect because the kidneys become resistant to calcitonin, as demonstrated by the overwhelming excretion of calcium in patients with thyroid tumors that secrete excess calcitonin.

In its skeletal-preserving action, calcitonin protects against calcium loss from the skeleton during periods of calcium mobilization, such as during pregnancy and especially lactation. The protective mechanism includes direct inhibition of bone resorption and indirect effects through inhibition of prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland.
Calcitonin is used to treat: postmenopausal osteoporosis, hypercalcemia, bone metastases
Calcitonin is used to treat: Paget's disease, phantom limb pain. It has been investigated as a potential non-operative treatment for spinal stenosis.
Disease_eng: Paget's disease, phantom limb pain, spinal stenosis

Medical Text_eng: Subcutaneous injection of calcitonin in patients with mania significantly reduces irritability, euphoria, and hyperactivity, and therefore calcitonin holds promise for the treatment of bipolar disorder. However, no further work has been reported on this potential application of calcitonin.

The drug is available in the form of a nasal spray and can also be administered as a shot. When calcitonin is injected into the body, it can cause some minor side effects such as fever and redness of the skin, vomiting, nausea, and skin swelling. When used as a nasal spray, it can cause nasal congestion, headaches, and bone pain, or even nosebleeds. In extremely rare cases, taking the drug through a nasal spray can cause an upset stomach or other stomach problems.

Insulin is the main hormone of the pancreas, a type of polypeptide, that regulates the entry of glucose from the blood into the cells. Insulin is secreted by the insulin-secreting cells of the pancreas (beta cells of the islets of Langerhans). Insulin is mainly used in diabetes mellitus. Insulin is a very ancient protein that was invented several billion years ago.
The hormone insulin helps in the synthesis of glycogen from glucose in the liver and muscles.
Insulin is a life-saving drug. In addition to type 1 diabetes, type 2 diabetes is a condition in which insulin is the only treatment option.

Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that is used to reduce acid production in the stomach. It is used to treat various conditions such as heartburn, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and stomach ulcers.
Pantoprazole helps relieve symptoms of acid reflux into the esophagus, such as heartburn and indigestion.
Pantoprazole helps heal ulcers in the stomach and duodenum and prevents new ulcers from forming.
Pantoprazole is usually taken once a day, on an empty stomach, 30 minutes before a meal.
Do not chew or break the tablet, swallow it whole.
Take your medication regularly as directed by your doctor.
If your condition does not improve or gets worse, contact your doctor.
Before taking pantoprazole, tell your doctor about your entire medical history and all medications you are taking.
Pantoprazole may interact with some medications, so talk to your doctor.
Talk to your doctor before taking pantoprazole if you have liver disease.
Taking pantoprazole for a long time may cause a decrease in bone density. Your doctor may monitor your bone health.
Before taking pantoprazole, tell your doctor if you have any allergies or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Pantoprazole can affect the results of some blood tests. Tell your doctor that you are taking pantoprazole.
Taking pantoprazole for a long time can cause low magnesium levels. Your doctor may monitor your magnesium levels.
Pantoprazole may increase the risk of certain infections, such as pneumonia and Clostridium difficile infection.
Metronidazole is an antibiotic against bacteria and protozoa that works by damaging the DNA of microbes.
Metronidazole is used to treat trichomoniasis, amoebiasis, bacterial vaginosis, and other infections.
Metronidazole is usually available in tablet, capsule, and liquid form to take by mouth.
Metronidazole is also available in cream and gel form.
Some common side effects of metronidazole are nausea, stomach pain, headache.
If you miss a dose of metronidazole, take it as soon as you remember.
Metronidazole may interact with some other medications, such as warfarin and disulfiram.
Metronidazole should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used to treat asthma and allergies.
Montelukast helps reduce inflammation and constriction in the airways, which improves asthma and allergy symptoms.
Montelukast is usually available as a tablet to take by mouth. It is also available as a chewable tablet and as a granule.
Some common side effects of montelukast are headache, stomach pain, nausea, and fever.
Talk to your doctor before taking montelukast if you have liver disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Keep montelukast medicine out of the reach of children and in a cool, dry place.
Minoxidil is a medication that is mainly used to prevent hair loss in men and women.
Minoxidil is available in liquid or foam form that is applied to the affected area twice a day.
How minoxidil works is not fully understood, but it is thought to help hair grow by stimulating hair follicles.
Some common side effects of minoxidil are tiny hair growth on the scalp, dryness or scaling of the skin, and irritation or redness of the scalp.
Talk to your doctor before using minoxidil if you have heart disease or high blood pressure.
Methylcobalamin is a form of vitamin B12 that is important for various functions in the body.
Methylcobalamin plays a role in DNA synthesis, nerve cell function, and blood cell production.
Methylcobalamin deficiency can cause anemia, neurological problems, and other health problems.
Methylcobalamin is usually available in tablet, capsule, or injection form.
Talk to your doctor before taking methylcobalamin, especially if you have any medical conditions or are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Methylprednisolone is a steroid that works to reduce inflammation in the body.
Methylprednisolone is used to treat asthma, allergies, arthritis, and many other conditions.
Methylprednisolone is usually available in tablet form to take by mouth.
Methylprednisolone is also available in injectable form.
The doctor will determine the dosage based on the severity of the patient's disease and other factors.
Some common side effects of methylprednisolone are weight gain, facial swelling, and trouble sleeping.
If you miss a dose of methylprednisolone, take it as soon as you remember.
Methylprednisolone can interact with some other medications, such as aspirin and diabetes medications.
Methylprednisolone should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Taking methylprednisolone during pregnancy and breastfeeding may be risky.
Talk to your doctor before taking methylprednisolone if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Metoprolol works by blocking the effects of certain natural chemicals in the heart that lower heart rate and blood pressure.
Metoprolol is used to treat high blood pressure, angina (chest pain), reduce the risk of heart disease after a heart attack, and control irregular heartbeats.
Metoprolol is usually taken once or twice a day, with or without food.
Metoprolol is available in tablet and capsule form.
Some common side effects of metoprolol are dizziness, fatigue, and cold hands and feet.
If you miss a dose of metoprolol, take it as soon as you remember.
Metoprolol may interact with some other medications, such as calcium channel blockers and digitalis.
Metoprolol should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Taking metoprolol during pregnancy and breastfeeding may be risky.
Talk to your doctor before taking metoprolol if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Melatonin is a hormone that helps regulate the sleep-wake cycle.
Melatonin is secreted in the dark and its secretion decreases in light.
Miconazole inhibits fungi by damaging the fungal cell membrane.
Miconazole is used to treat fungal infections of the skin, such as athlete's foot, jock itch, and ringworm.
Miconazole is also used to treat vaginal yeast infections and oral thrush.
Miconazole is usually applied to the skin in the form of creams, lotions, powders, and sprays.
The doctor will determine the dosage and method of application of miconazole based on the severity of the patient's infection and other factors.
Some common side effects of miconazole are skin irritation, itching, and redness.
Using miconazole for vaginal yeast infections can cause vaginal irritation and itching.
Methimazole is an antithyroid medication used to reduce excess hormone production by the thyroid gland.
Methimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism.
Methimazole is usually taken once or twice a day, with or without food.
Some common side effects of methimazole are nausea, stomach pain, itching, and loss of appetite.
If you miss a dose of methimazole, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next dose of methimazole, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule.
There are some precautions you should take when taking methimazole. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Methimazole should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take several weeks to several months to see results from taking methimazole.
Meclizine is an antihistamine that works by blocking certain receptors in the brain.
Meclizine is used to treat nausea, vomiting, and dizziness caused by motion sickness, vertigo, and Ménière's disease.
Meclizine is usually taken as needed.
For motion sickness, take one tablet of meclizine one hour before traveling.
Some common side effects of meclizine include drowsiness, dry mouth, and blurred vision.
If you miss a dose of meclizine, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next dose of meclizine, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule.
There are some precautions you should take when taking meclizine. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Meclizine should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Meclizine begins to take effect shortly after taking it.
Meloxicam is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that acts as a COX-2 inhibitor.
Meloxicam is used to treat osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and other pain and inflammatory conditions.
Meloxicam is usually taken once a day with or without food.
Meloxicam is available in tablet and capsule form.
Some common side effects of meloxicam are stomach pain, nausea, headache, and dizziness.
If you miss a dose of meloxicam, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next dose of meloxicam, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule.

There are some precautions you should take when taking meloxicam. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have heart, liver, or kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Meloxicam should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take a few days to a few weeks to see full results after taking meloxicam.
Magnesium hydroxide is an antacid and laxative.
Magnesium hydroxide neutralizes stomach acid, relieving heartburn and indigestion.
Magnesium hydroxide draws water into the intestines, which softens stool and relieves constipation.
Magnesium hydroxide is usually taken as needed.
For heartburn and indigestion, take magnesium hydroxide after meals and before bed.
For constipation, take magnesium hydroxide before bed as it will help with bowel movements in the morning.
Some common side effects of magnesium hydroxide are upset stomach, diarrhea, and nausea.
If you miss a dose of magnesium hydroxide, take it as soon as you remember.
Some precautions should be taken when taking magnesium hydroxide.
There are some precautions you should take when taking magnesium hydroxide. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Magnesium hydroxide should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Magnesium hydroxide begins to take effect within a few hours of taking it.
Magnesium citrate is a saline laxative.
Magnesium citrate is used to relieve constipation.
Some common side effects of magnesium citrate are upset stomach, diarrhea, and nausea.
Some precautions should be taken when taking magnesium citrate.
Magnesium citrate should be stored in a cool, dry place.
Magnesium citrate begins to take effect within 30 minutes to 6 hours after taking it.
If you sneeze, you should cover your face with a handkerchief.
If you have stomach pain, you should see a doctor.
Sitting in front of the computer for a long time puts strain on the eyes.
If dust gets in your eyes, do not rub them with your hands.
If you have a toothache, you should go to the dentist.
Don't forget to clean your tongue after brushing your teeth.
If you have pain, apply warm water to the painful area.
Gargling with salt in warm water reduces sore throat.
Kidney patients should drink more water.
If you have severe stomach pain, you should see a doctor.
Brush twice a day to protect your teeth.
If the watery eyes do not stop flowing, consult an ophthalmologist.
Regular exercise is good for the heart.
If you have a cut anywhere on your body, you should first clean the area thoroughly.
A cold can cause a sore throat.
If you have a sore throat, you should gargle.
If you have a head injury, definitely consult a doctor.
If you feel dizzy, you should rest.
Eating honey is beneficial for cough.
Many eye diseases can be prevented by getting regular eye checkups.
Drinking a glass of water on an empty stomach every morning is good for the stomach.
If you have stomach pain, you may have intestinal problems.
The patient suffered a brain hemorrhage due to severe head trauma.
Eating too much sugar causes tooth decay.
My nose is blocked due to a cold.
Use lip balm regularly to prevent chapped lips during winter.

It may take a few weeks to see full results after taking niacinamide.
Nimesulide is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) and antipyretic that acts as a COX-2 inhibitor.
Pharmacological Class_eng: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), COX-2 inhibitors, antipyretics

Medical Text_eng: Nimesulide is used to reduce pain and inflammation, especially in cases of osteoarthritis and menstrual pain.
Nimesulide is available in tablet, capsule, and liquid forms.
Some common side effects of nimesulide are stomach pain, nausea, indigestion, and dizziness.
Disease_eng: Stomach pain, nausea, indigestion and dizziness

Medical Text_eng: If you miss a dose of nimesulide, take it as soon as you remember.

There are some precautions you should take while taking nimesulide. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have heart, liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Nimesulide should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
When there are joint problems, such as arthritis, nimesulide is used to reduce pain, swelling, and inflammation.
Naproxen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by reducing the production of a chemical called prostaglandin.
Naproxen is used to relieve headaches, toothaches, menstrual pain, muscle pain, and arthritis pain.
Disease_eng: Headache, Toothache, Menstrual pain, Muscle pain, Arthritis

Medical Text_eng: Naproxen is usually taken two to three times a day, with or without food.
Naproxen is available in tablet, capsule, and liquid forms.
If you miss a dose of naproxen, take it as soon as you remember.

There are some precautions you should take when taking naproxen. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have heart, liver, or kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Naproxen should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Naproxen begins to take effect within a few hours after taking it.
Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that works by inhibiting the DNA replication process of bacteria.
Ofloxacin is used to treat various bacterial infections like bronchitis, pneumonia, infectious diarrhea, prostatitis, etc.
Ofloxacin is usually taken twice a day with or without food.
Ofloxacin is available in tablet form.
Some common side effects of ofloxacin are nausea, stomach pain, headache, and dizziness.
If you miss a dose of ofloxacin, take it as soon as you remember.
There are some precautions you should take when taking ofloxacin. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Ofloxacin should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take a few days to show full results after taking ofloxacin.
Estrogen is a steroid hormone that plays an important role in regulating mammalian reproduction.
The ovaries, adrenal glands, and adipose tissue produce estrogen.
Organ_eng: Ovaries, adrenal glands, and adipose tissue

Medical Text_eng: In women, estrogen prepares the uterus and other reproductive organs for pregnancy.
Estrogen affects various organs, including the ovaries, vagina, uterus, and breasts.
Estrogen tablets serve a variety of medical purposes. Doctors primarily prescribe them to manage the symptoms of menopause as part of hormone replacement therapy.
Estrogen tablets help relieve hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and painful intercourse.
The dosage of estrogen varies based on the specific condition and the patient's individual needs.
Rabeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).
Rabeprazole works by reducing the production of acid in the stomach.
Rabeprazole is used to treat GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease), ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome.
Disease_eng: GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease), Ulcer, Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome

Medical Text_eng: Rabeprazole is available in tablet form.
If you miss a dose of rabeprazole, take it as soon as you remember.
Some precautions should be taken while taking rabeprazole.
Rabeprazole should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take a few days to a few weeks to see full results after taking rabeprazole.
Soframycin is an antibiotic cream used to treat bacterial infections of the skin.
Soframycin contains an antibiotic called framycetin, which prevents the growth of bacteria.
Soframycin is used to treat skin wounds, cuts, and infections.
Soframycin is available in cream form and should be applied to the affected area two to three times a day.
Before using soframycin, the affected area should be thoroughly cleaned and dried.
Some common side effects of soframycin include skin irritation, itching, and redness.
Talk to your doctor or pharmacist before using soframycin if you have any other medical conditions or are taking any other medications.
Soframycin should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Symptoms of infection will begin to subside within a few days after using soframycin.
Soroglitazar is a PPAR agonist that works in the liver.
Soroglitazar is used to treat type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia.
Soroglitazar is usually taken once a day with food.
Soroglitazar is available in tablet form.
If you miss a dose of saroglitazar, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next dose of saroglitazar, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule.
There are some precautions you should take when taking soroglitazar. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Soroglitazar should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take several weeks to see full results after taking soroglitazar.
Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that works by reducing the breakdown of incretin hormones.
Sitagliptin helps control blood sugar levels in type 2 diabetes.
Sitagliptin is available in tablet form.
Some common side effects of sitagliptin are headache, nasal congestion, sore throat, and upset stomach.
If you miss a dose of sitagliptin, take it as soon as you remember.
Some precautions should be taken while taking sitagliptin.
Sitagliptin should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take several weeks to see full results after taking sitagliptin.
Promethazine is a phenothiazine class drug that is primarily used as an antipsychotic.
Promethazine is used to treat mental disorders, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
Phenothiazines are also used to prevent nausea and vomiting and as antihistamines.
Phenothiazines are available in tablet and injection form.
If you miss a dose of promethazine, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next phenothiazine dose, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule.
There are some precautions you should take when taking promethazine. For example, talk to your doctor before taking it if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Promethazine should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Piroxicam is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that acts as a COX inhibitor and works by reducing the production of a chemical called prostaglandin.
Piroxicam is used to treat osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and other pain and inflammatory conditions.
Piroxicam is available in tablet and capsule form.
If you miss a dose of piroxicam, take it as soon as you remember.
Some precautions should be taken while taking piroxicam.
Piroxicam should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
It may take a few days to a few weeks to see full results after taking piroxicam.
Prednisone is a steroid that works to reduce inflammation in the body.
Prednisone is used to treat asthma, allergies, arthritis, and many other diseases.
Prednisone is usually available in tablet form to take by mouth.
Prednisone is also available in injectable form.
The doctor will determine the dose of prednisone based on the severity of the patient's disease and other factors.
Some common side effects of prednisone are weight gain, facial swelling, and sleep problems.
If you miss a dose of prednisone, take it as soon as you remember.
However, if it is almost time for your next prednisone dose, skip the missed dose and follow your regular schedule.
Prednisone can interact with some other medications, such as aspirin and diabetes medications.
Prednisone should be stored in a dry place, at room temperature.
Taking prednisone during pregnancy and breastfeeding can be risky.
Talk to your doctor before taking prednisone if you have liver or kidney disease or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Loratadine is a widely used antihistamine that relieves the annoying symptoms of allergies such as sneezing, itching, and watery eyes.
Disease_eng: Sneezing, itching, and watery eyes are allergies.

Medical Text_eng: Loratadine relieves sneezing, runny nose, itchy nose or throat, and watery eyes.

Your first aid box must have everything – antiseptic cream/solution, gauze, adhesive plaster, roller bandage, scissors, basic painkillers, thermometer to BP monitor etc. It should be kept in a place that is safe and easily accessible. Checking the expiry dates and replacing expired items is another aspect that should not be missed.
Common Medical Terms_eng: Nociseptic cream/solution, gauze, adhesive plaster, roller bandage, scissors, basic painkillers, thermometer to BP monitor

Medical Text_eng: Migraine in children is a complex and disabling condition that affects approximately 4% to 10% of young people. These severe headaches not only affect a child's physical well-being but also their educational performance and social life.

When a child experiences a migraine, it is crucial to provide a calm and comfortable environment. Encourage the child to rest in a quiet, dark room with a cool cloth on their forehead. Make sure they stay hydrated and consider giving them over-the-counter pain relief medications as prescribed by their doctor. Keeping a migraine diary can help identify triggers and patterns. Maintaining a regular sleep schedule, diet, and exercise routine are also essential to preventing future attacks.
